text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

I am a surgical oncologist who treats patients with melanoma on a daily basis. I have treated numerous patients in their 20's and 30's whose major risk factor for skin cancer is using a tanning salon as a minor. Several of these patients have died as a result of their melanoma.

As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.

Prevention of minors use of tanning salons will go a long way towards prevention of melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer.

I support efforts to make indoor tanning equipment safer but believe that if I am fully informed of any consequences of tanning, I should have the ability to do so.

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-TRI-2016-0390

I am in strong support of the proposed rule that would require the addition of Natural Gas Processing facilities (NGP) to report to the TRI. Full disclosure will help both communities and the industry operate more efficiently.

Thank you for your time.
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

I and a lot of family and friends worry about this rule change causing confusion among the general public regarding honey labels.

It sounds like you are planning to label honey as having "added sugars", causing people to think the product is not real, or pure honey, but adulterated honey, with sugar "added" by humans to stretch it out.

Please avoid this confusion and list the naturally occurring sugars content of 100% pure honey as "Total Sugars" and not "Added Sugars." Better yet, you could create a separate sub-category under "Total Sugars" for "Naturally Occurring Sugars".

Thank you!

I am writing about my opinion concerning requiring the language of "added sugars" to be placed on honey labels.  My husband and I sell our honey at farmers' markets in Seattle.  Many of our customers, especially those born overseas, ask us about added sugar.  What they are asking is whether or not we adulterate our honey with sugar syrups.  If we had an item like "added sugar" on the label it would mislead them into thinking that our honey was adulterated.  We would prefer a term like "total sugar" to represent the sugar in our pure honey product.  Just as a sweet product like unsweetened applesauce has sugar but not added sugar or syrups, so our honey has sugar but not "added sugar".

Submitting comments on EPA-HQ-TRI-2016-0390

Please do not withdraw request that operators of existing oil and gas wells provide the EPA with information about methane emissions. Methane has been proven to cause more damage to the environment than CO2. It's warming potential is significantly higher than carbon dioxide. It traps up to 100 times more heat in the atmosphere than CO2 within a five year period. The quickest way to cool the planet is to reduce methane gas emissions in the atmosphere. The only way to do this is to monitor the level of emissions.

EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

Dear FDA:

I join with the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express my concern of the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.
If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
I realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.
I share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice and promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.
As a beekeeper I encourage the FDA to consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."

As a small producer of honey I find that while your efforts to regulate the purity of food products is a noble cause, we as
beekeepers in a small scale face enough hurdles trying to keep our bees alive. this effort on your part will place one more
stumbling block in our path. The small amount of revenue generated by the sale of small amounts of honey is crucial to my
ability to break even in a very expensive hobby and that along with all the other pressures we face could be the last step in
putting myself and many other small scale beekeepers out of the craft. Beekeepers on the hobby level ( I have seven hives
currently) are a very important part of the pollination process and it takes every beekeeper both large and small to make
pollination happen. Make your rules apply to suppliers of honey for the grocery store chains not us who sell from our homes
or at our local farmers market. Please, large scale regulation by big government organizations is going to stifle a cottage
industry that serves a vital purpose in our communities.

We are a small family business. People buy our honey because it is simply all natural, a PURE product. putting a label on stating it has added sugars will defiantly turn customers away. I have see it before at markets. Customers pick up a jar, read the nutrition information, then come and buy from me because I have no nutrition information on mine. When they see that label saying added sugars they run! "Added  sugar" is a bad word in the food world these days. And when it comes to pure honey its a flat out lie.  People just want to by REAL FOOD!! Why do we have to make that more difficult than it already is?
No to the Organic Checkoff!!!!

RIDICULOUS, RIDICULOUS waste of taxpayer time and dollars to present this as if you've spent any time trying to solve the problem of Healthcare here.

Did you think the problem was people living too long?
Did you think the problem was people keeping too much of their own hard-earned money?
Did you think the problem was insurance companies not giving enough in bonuses to their CEOs?

WELL CONGRATUFREAKINLATIONS YOU SOLVED THOSE PROBLEMS. Idiots.

Do it again, and do it right.

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
docAbstract: Open

text:
I strongly oppose the government's proposed change to how I choose to spend my time, my money, and how I stay healthy. The tanning salon industry already has many safety precautions in place to protect myself as well as my family members; requiring protective eyewear, tanning limits etc.
I am a user of indoor tanning beds and am well aware of the risks. I do not appreciate that the federal government feels the need to take anymore of my civil liberties by putting restrictions on my pursuit of happiness.
I live in a climate that tends to be cold and dark in the winter and I utilize indoor tanning for my personal well being. There are many studies that have shown UV rays be they fake or real do provide positive health benefits. For me personally, tanning during the long winter months DOES increase my energy and mood.
I think the government has much better things to worry about, spend money on, as well as spend time making laws about other than my use of indoor tanning beds.

I urge you to please stay out of my personal business. Please, let me take care of MY BODY the way I choose. To utilize indoor tanning as often as I can is MY CHOICE to make not the government's to take away.
Whats next? Regulations on how many cans of Coke or Pepsi I can purchase and drink per day. There are studies that show sitting in front of computers all day is unhealthy. Eating too much bacon is bad for you. Just getting in my car to drive to work could maybe end in disaster.

Please, I appeal to your common sense that humans around the world are capable of make their own choices and decisions regarding their body and what to do with them and how to take care of them. Do not go forward with the proposed changes to the already established safety rules of how often I will be allowed to utilize my indoor tanning salon. Thank you!!
docAbstract: Open

text:
We are beekeepers and our bees make their own honey. We don't add anything to it. It is not pure honey if we do. There
should only be PURE HONEY written on the labels. Nothing added.

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

I am a hobby beekeeper, and also a physician, specializing in diabetes.  I believe that America's over consumption of sugar is contributing to a crisis of metabolic disorders including type 2 diabetes.  Giving consumers a mechanism to see what foods have added sugars, allowing them to be distinguished from natural sugars is a great idea.  However, I am disturbed to hear that pure honey could require such an "added sugar" label.  This reflects a lack of understanding of what honey is and how it is produced.  Unadulterated honey has no added sugar.  The sugar in honey comes directly from the nectar that our bees collect.  The bees partially digest the sugars in the nectar and concentrate it in their hives, producing honey.   The only processing required is to separate the honey from the combs.  Once that is done, the honey can be used raw or heated, but nothing is added. Raw honey may have benefits of improving tolerance to local pollens for pollen allergy sufferers.   Honey producers are not only making their living "growing" honey, but they are providing valuable pollinators in the midst of a pollinator crisis.   At the same time, they are struggling to protect their market from adulterated products that are not pure honey.  Putting "added sugar" on the label of pure honey is not only not accurate, it will confuse consumers, and make it more difficult for them to recognize and purchase pure honey.  Please reconsider requiring an added sugar label for honey.

Dear FDA (most consider you our government, but you are human beings and people with good intentions)
I'm a small sideline beekeeper in northeast Florida. As a consumer the labeling of sugar in honey is somewhat confusing. We know it is about 84 percent total (natural) sugars,a few minerals, amino acids, vitamins, yeasts, and water. It has an acidic pH,and resists natural degradation when sealed from moisture. It can be stored for periods longer than human's natural lives, and is collected by an insect that lives about 6 weeks on average. Changing the law with respect to the disclosure of Total and Added sugars of Honey does not on the surface properly inform the public, unless you believe it is more than twice as dangerous a product. Due to the nature of honey starting its life as nectar (sucrose sugar) from a flower, what does the impact of further labeling Honey with the same amount of added sugars on the label reveal to the consumer? It has a doubling inference and I do not believe that is the correct form of disclosure, or the intended message of our labeling laws. As a consumer I do not want a label that is overstated or misleading, that would make me believe that I am consuming something detrimental to my health. And as a result I would not purchase the product or consume the product. As a businessman, the implication of added sugar to a product leads me to believe there is adulteration. There are too many beekeepers who protect their product from the concept of adulteration that will be materially impacted by this reclassification. So as both a consumer and a beekeeper I would ask and urge you to exempt pure Honey, from the requirement of an Added Sugars disclosure in the proposed label law changes. I do not believe your intent is to misinform the public, or correct something at a later date that can be resolved prior to the law (FDA 2016-D-4414-0002) taking effect. There are over four thousand registered beekeepers in Florida. I would hope all will comment on the proposed changes you are recommending, but know only a few have the time to keep up to date with changing laws until they are required to comply. I would hope that by the time this letter is read you are already convinced that pure Honey is a unique product and have already made the decision to eliminate the disclosure requirement. I believe the FDA is the watch dog of the food chain, and that you are making progress by proactively informing the public to improve food safety and personal health. I also believe you have the public's best interest in mind when you create new laws. Thank you for your consideration as to my request.
Respectfully, Don Peppers, Beekeeper

This "added sugars" rule, if applied to products like honey, will be completely misleading to consumers. I am not a beekeeper nor do I sell honey. But I buy honey and I do read labels. If I lead a label that says "added sugars" to honey, I will assume that this means that sugar has been added to the honey, which, by its very nature, already contains sugar. In fact, no sugar has been "added" to a jar of natural honey because there's only natural honey, no additional sugar, in the jar. No consumer in the world will realize that the "added sugars" label is supposed to mean is: "how much sugar am I adding to my diet if I purchase this honey or other natural sugar-containing product?" Why is the FDA choosing to adopt this weird interpretation of what should be plain language? If I buy a jar of natural honey, that no one has added corn syrup to, it contains sugar; no sugar has been added to it. Please change this rule, FDA! The "added sugars" label should only apply to products where sugar is actually added, by the manufacturer or producer, to the already-existing product. I depend on you to make my life as a consumer easier, not more difficult. Thank you.

As a stakeholder,I support the organic check-offproposed rule(AMS-SC-16-0112).

Thank you for this opportunity to providecommenton the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs)proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order.

Stakeholderslook forward to the Department consideringcomments fromcertified organic operationswho would be assessed in such a program, andmoving to anindustryvote as soon as possible.Congress, in the 2014 Farm Bill, supported by a strong bipartisan vote in both the House and Senate Agriculture Committees authorized the organic sector to submit an application to create a check-off nearly three years ago; and USDA has been considering this application for over 18 months. The organic sector applauds AMSs work on the proposed rule, appreciates the challenges that come with designing a check-off program for an entire multi-commodity sector, andlooks forward to a final rule andindustryvote so we can move forwardtoward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.

The check-off model provides a tried and true vehicle for the organic sector to invest our own dollars in our collective continued growth at no cost to the taxpayer. An organic check-off program would generate money for the organic sector to educate consumers about what organic is and its benefits; distinguish organic from other claims; undertake research to solve problems like invasive pests and weed control; bring new farmers into organic through information and technical assistance; and reduce the supply crunch by transitioning farmland to organic production. Moreover, the creation of an organic check-off would enable the organic sector to access public dollars that are only available to those who generate matching funds a significant resource that as of yet the organic sector has been unable to access.

The proposed rule is very reform-minded and unlike any other check-off that has preceded it.This proposal resolves what has not worked in other check-offs and emphasizes what works representing the diversity and creative thinking that has always been a hallmark of the organic sector.

Organic operations like mine want to use the check-off mechanism to help ourselves respond to research, education, promotion, and information challenges. The time is right for this and were excitedto move toward a final rule andindustryvoteand acting collectively to ensure a strong future.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity tocomment, andI urgeUSDA to move to anindustryvote as soon as possible.

Organic check-off will not help farmers, ranchers, processors or anyone in between.  The organic movement has been built from the ground up and remains very viable through hardworking grassroots people who care about the environment and their health.  There is no need for a organic check-off.  It will only disrupt the strong system of natural farmer to consumer relationship.

I strongly SUPPORT the proposed Lake Michigan National Marine Sanctuary in Lake Michigan off Algoma, Manitowoc, Sheboygan, and Port Washington. As an archaeologist and ethnohistorian, I keep up with the discoveries and the issues with shipwrecks in this area, and also with sites affected by shoreline changes. The amount of knowledge to be protected by the proposed sanctuary is enormous, and much of it directly valuable to property titles. Please APPROVE the designation of this Lake Michigan National Marine Sanctuary.
--Alice Kehoe, Prof. of Anthropology, emeritus, Marquette University
docAbstract: NOAA is proposing to designate an area of 1,075 square miles of Wisconsin state waters as the Wisconsin – Lake Michigan National Marine Sanctuary (WLMNMS or sanctuary). NOAA also proposes regulations to implement the sanctuary designation and establish the sanctuary’s terms of designation. A draft environmental impact statement and draft management plan have also been prepared for this proposed action.

Thank you, James L Hardman, Longmont, CO
docAbstract: EPA is proposing regulations under Section 108(b) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) that will require certain classes within the Hard Rock Mining Industry to establish and maintain evidence of financial responsibility consistent with the degree and duration of risk association with the production, transportation, treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous substances.

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
docAbstract: Open

text: i am strongly opposed to the new regylations on tanning beds.
docAbstract: Open

text: It is my opinion that too much of anything may not be good for your health. It is the FDA responsibility to inform not enforce. If your going to ban recreational sun bathing for minors, but not  require the same restrictions  for fast food retail like Mc donalds, the policy is unjust and biased.
docAbstract: Open

text: I understand and appreciate the FDA's efforts to protect consumers by regulating tanning bed exposure.  I find the restrictions against tanning no more than once every 24 hours completely reasonable, as well as restricting the age at which individuals can start using tanning beds.  However, I am not in favor of the FDA regulating how many times per week or year I am permitted to tan.  As a consenting adult, I fully understand the risks involved in indoor tanning and feel that I have the ability to safely regulate myself without imposed government restrictions on my personal choices.
docAbstract: Open

text: Tanning beds should be banned altogether. No amount of tanning is safe. A tan is skin damage! My mother has melanoma from teen years in the sun and I have skin cancers removed regularly. Individual and public cost of treating skin cancer is huge. Stopping tanning bed use by teens is a good first step, since these kids feel immortal and make lousy health choices.
docAbstract: Open

docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
RE: Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765] General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products

I am the Executive Director and founder of Childrens Melanoma Prevention Foundation (CMPF). It is a non-profit educational foundation, established in 2003, to teach children and their caretakers safe and proven methods of sun protection and skin cancer prevention. Our aim is to reduce the incidence and impact of melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, on families and society. Each year, CMPF reaches over 100,000 children locally and thousands of health professionals nationally with our SunAWARE message. CMPF partnered with other stakeholders to successfully advocate for an indoor tanning ban for minors in Massachusetts this year.

As an oncology and dermatology nurse, I have been extremely concerned about children exposing themselves to concentrated doses of UV radiation, a proven human carcinogen, to achieve skin darkening for cosmetic reasons. I recently published an article entitled, Skin Cancer a Growing Health Problem for Children. In this review article, I examined the National Cancer Institutes Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database and found that melanoma was not only on the rise but was actually the 4th most common cancer in children. Most importantly, I found that 72% of pediatric melanoma cases occurred in the girls between the ages of 15 to 19 years old. Most people think that pediatric cancers develop due to a genetic predisposition or inherent risk factors. However, this distribution of melanoma cases in young girls clearly indicates that risk for this population is acquired rather than inherited. A history of indoor tanning is a known acquired risk factor for melanoma and children must be protected from this harmful practice.

A recent study published by Lazovich et al found that younger women who had tanned indoors experienced a 2.3- to 6-fold increased likelihood of developing melanoma. This correlation between tanning and melanoma was particularly evident among women diagnosed with melanoma in their 20s. Our foundation is very concerned about these case controlled studies but also concerned by anecdotal stories that we hear in the
classroom. Some students report indoor tanning more that once a day and many students report using no eye protection. One 16-year-old girl said that she had opened her eyes in the tanning bed to see what I was not supposed to see. Another teenage boy told us that he was severely burned when the operator, his classmate, allowed him to extend his session in the super bed to twenty minutes. I believe that the only way to protect children from the hazards of indoor tanning is to issue a national ban.

This year, Massachusetts became the 12th state to ban minors from indoor tanning. Our ban will go into effect just in time for prom season on May 5, 2016. In addition, it will be difficult for most children in Massachusetts to indoor tan before the prom because our surrounding states also have restrictions. We need a nationwide ban to protect all children from this proven human carcinogen and to reduce their risk for developing skin cancer. Every child and adolescent in the U.S., regardless of the state in which he or she resides, deserves to be protected from UV radiation from sunlamps. We believe that state-by-state efforts may be inadequate and CMPF fully supports the FDAs efforts to protect all Americans with this proposed rule restricting indoor tanning for minors.

We commend the FDA for issuing a proposed rule to restrict the use of indoor tanning equipment for minors. We believe that this proposed rule is a critical step in promoting the Surgeon Generals fourth goal in his 2014 Call to Action to Prevent Skin Cancer. This goal to reduce harm caused by indoor tanning is one step in preventing skin cancer in America. We strongly urge the FDA to finalize the proposed rule and protect all children in America from the harmful effects of indoor tanning.

text:
Added sugar in pure honey?!?!? This will confuse consumers and allow sub par products (unadulterated honey) to be sold as equal to the real thing. This will be very bad for not only the industry, but the general population as well. BAD IDEA!
Please fix this.

I am an 8th year beekeeper that depends on surplus honey sales income to support costs of beekeeping and provide a small second income for myself. See following as I fear and agree that to label honey sugars with the terminology "added sugar" will be detrimental to honey sales:

We recognize that honey is a source of sugar added to foods; however, there is nothing added to pure honey itself.
Listing the sugar content in honey as "Added Sugars" on the nutrition facts label implies adulteration of honey in its natural form.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
Consumers will be misled to believe that honey is sweetened by adding an external sugar source rather than the naturally occurring sugars inherent in honey.
There is a risk of consumer confusion if the nutrition facts label notes "Added Sugars" but a separate area on the label notes "naturally occurring sugar." By definition, something added cannot also be naturally occurring. Our research shows that this will cause consumer confusion that hinders their ability to make informed food choices.
We realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.
We share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.
Our desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey
To that end, we are asking that the FDA consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."

In you proposal, you would have honey labels list "added sugars"  There are no sugars "added" to honey.  Having honey producers list "added sugars" to identify how much sugar is in honey is inappropriate.  It is an incorrect understanding of what honey is and suggests that the honey has been "added to" or adulterated.  It would be more appropriate to have honey list "total sugars" because it does naturally come with a sugar content but there are NO added sugars to pure honey.
In no way should "pure honey" be labeled as "added sugars". Pure honey is just that pure honey.

As an organic processor, I vehemently oppose the Organic Check off tax.  Both the burden of additional cost and the lack of control over the expenditure of the fund make support impossible.

Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

If repealing & replacing doesn't result in Trump's promise of a better, cheaper, covers everybody health care plan, why is anything less being brought forward? Back to the drawing board if you cannot truly do better than Obamacare. You might as well consider and enact something like the UK's NHS. It costs half of what our uniquely American system does. Why wouldn't we want that sort of doubling of an national economic benefit? Or go with Medicare for all? I thought national economics was Trump's uniting theme? You can always make additional private health insurance optional to those who want to pay for it. But look out for all of us, active, retired, disabled, etc. not just those lucking enough to have a job that pays for benefits. And seriously, the rich do not need one more set of tax cuts nor do insurance CEO's need their own special tax cut bribe. Eisenhauer pointed out that only when the rich are taxed to a significant degree, and the wealth run through programs benefiting the lower classes, do they actually make new investments in domestic production, pay living wages, and grow America in a way that lifts us all. Even Reagan's tax cuts didn't take the richest levels under 50%. With the only the rich getting the majority of benefits of economic boom, it's clear a real change is needed. Health care is just one leg of a 3 legged stool to restore the true possibility of security and prosperity to the lower and middle classes. Restoring pension programs is another key leg. Raising minimum wage is the 3rd leg. Or go do what your ---- masters have dictated to you and betray 350,000,000 real Americans. Wasn't Trump supposed to stand up to just this sort of corruption in politics?

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765
As an employee in the indoor tanning industry, I strongly oppose the FDAs proposal to ban tanning by minors and to require customers to sign a risk acknowledgement form every six months. Our customers enjoy tanning for a variety of reasons, and for the reasons outlined below, no further government regulation is needed.
First, the decision of whether a minor should tan, be that outdoors in the sun or indoors at a tanning salon (that enforces limited tan times and other safety precautions), is best left to parents, not the federal government. Most states already require parental consent for minors to tan indoors, ensuring the parent has input and approval.
In addition, we have many teenage clients who are referred to indoor tanning by their doctor or dermatologist to treat skin conditions. Why should these clients be required to obtain these services at a dermatology office which is much more expensive than at an indoor tanning salon?
If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons which enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.
Next, requiring adults to sign a risk acknowledgement certification every six months in order to use a sunbed is absurd. Our customers are already required to acknowledge risk before their first session; requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare and tremendous burden to our salon employees, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat, that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require such a form in our business and not for the hundreds of products and services which present many more dangers than UV exposure.
For all of these reasons, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional regulations.
docAbstract: Open

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Dear FDA,

As a consumer, I am concerned about the new legislation proposed for nutrition labels as it pertains to pure, jarred honey. I have read that adding the line, "added sugars," to the labeling requirements is intended to differentiate between healthy and "empty" calories, and I agree that this is a good thing to communicate. If this was the differentiation that I as a consumer would see, I would be 100% for it.

Unfortunately, the label information, as currently written, does not communicate this. It communicates to the consumer that the beekeeping and honey industry is adding sugars to our honey, when in fact it is a pure and whole food that has not been altered in any way. As there have been numerous accounts recently of adulterated honey entering the US market, and selling adulterated honey is illegal, forcing beekeepers to say that they have added sugars to their honey (making it adulterated), when they have not, will be bad for both consumers and beekeepers. The end result will be further confusion from the nutrition label, rather than clarification.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

My name is Tish Dutson and I live in central Maine and have been keeping bees for over 30 years.  It has come to my attention that the FDA is proposing labeling requirements for honey and that "added sugars" is part of the wording.  PLEASE note that having to add this wording will totally confuse consumers.   With the popularity of natural foods, I think having to add this wording to honey would be extremely detrimental to my sales. I am in total opposition with this wording.  Thank-you for your time.

As a sideline beekeeper for the past 10 years, there has never been one once of sugar fed or added to my beehives during honey season when honey supers are on the hive.
As with everything in government bureaucracy, you want to paint all producers with one brush.
If you are having a problem with Chinese and imported honey coming in with added corn syrup and sugars being added, address that problem for what it is.
What you are doing to the American Bee Keeper in piling more red tape and regulations on us, which in turn adds additional cost to the product, which makes our product, which is already a pure unadulterated honey, more expensive to produce and cast doubts as to its unadulterated purity.
If you are not aware, in America, Bee keepers are taught from the time they enter the production of honey that it is a cardinal rule never to feed your bees when there is a honey supper sitting on the hive.
Contrary to your belief in our integrity, you are making a problem with the American honey market where there is no problem at all.
I would suggest that you concentrate on the imported honey that is ruining our honey market in the U.S. with cheap, adulterated, imported honey. This is the real problem that your bureaucracy should be concentrating on and making rules for importers of honey that are flooding our market with this product that no American bee keeper would dare to sell to his customers or even feed his bees most of this imported product.
I will be sending a copy of this on to my legislators in the house and senate and asking them to have some oversight what your agency is doing to the American bee keeper.
Sincerely,
James J. Ring,
Maggie Valley NC
American Bee Keeper

As a beekeeper and consumer I feel that requiring honey to be labeled as Contains Added Sugars is not only misleading but untrue. I add no sugar to my honey nor do my bees. The sugars contained in honey are from the natural nectar source from which they were collected.

This label would imply that honey is only flavored sugar water and thus reduce the value of bees in the public's eyes at a time when bees need all of the help they can get.

Gentlemen,

The label as proposed regarding raw, natural honey would be miss leading. Honey is a natural product that contain sugars from its source, but no sugars have been additionally added to this all natural product of nature. A consumer reading the label as proposed could easily interpret this natural product to have been adulterated by the addition of some additional sugar substance like high fructose corn syrup or other sweetening agent. An all natural and healthful product like raw or natural honey is vital to many for its dietary benefits and the label as now proposed would mislead the public whom labels with nutritional facts are supposed to protect and inform. Please reconsider this proposal and allow raw and natural honey to be label correctly as having no sugars added. Thank you.

Almost every other large industry has to report to the TRI, from manufacturers to power plants to coal mines. But the oil and gas extraction industry has been exempt from the TRI reporting. It makes no sense that they should be exempt since they produce and release lots of toxins into the environment.

Information from the TRI has proven to be very useful: communities have used it to plan for their future; regulators have used it to set the right controls; and the industries themselves have actually used it to reduce their toxic releases.

These toxins MUST be reported so we can keep people and the environment safe from the harm they are known to cause.

I have personally met people whose lives have been shattered by Natural Gas Processing Facilities. It would be negligent to exempt these facilities any longer.
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

As a stakeholder,I support the organic check-offproposed rule(AMS-SC-16-0112).

Thank you for this opportunity to providecommenton the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs)proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order.

Stakeholderslook forward to the Department consideringcomments fromcertified organic operationswho would be assessed in such a program, andmoving to anindustryvote as soon as possible.Congress, in the 2014 Farm Bill, supported by a strong bipartisan vote in both the House and Senate Agriculture Committees authorized the organic sector to submit an application to create a check-off nearly three years ago; and USDA has been considering this application for over 18 months. The organic sector applauds AMSs work on the proposed rule, appreciates the challenges that come with designing a check-off program for an entire multi-commodity sector, andlooks forward to a final rule andindustryvote so we can move forwardtoward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.

The check-off model provides a tried and true vehicle for the organic sector to invest our own dollars in our collective continued growth at no cost to the taxpayer. An organic check-off program would generate money for the organic sector to educate consumers about what organic is and its benefits; distinguish organic from other claims; undertake research to solve problems like invasive pests and weed control; bring new farmers into organic through information and technical assistance; and reduce the supply crunch by transitioning farmland to organic production. Moreover, the creation of an organic check-off would enable the organic sector to access public dollars that are only available to those who generate matching funds a significant resource that as of yet the organic sector has been unable to access.

The proposed rule is very reform-minded and unlike any other check-off that has preceded it.This proposal resolves what has not worked in other check-offs and emphasizes what works representing the diversity and creative thinking that has always been a hallmark of the organic sector.

Organic operations like mine want to use the check-off mechanism to help ourselves respond to research, education, promotion, and information challenges. The time is right for this and were excitedto move toward a final rule andindustryvoteand acting collectively to ensure a strong future.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity tocomment, andI urgeUSDA to move to anindustryvote as soon as possible.

Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

Based on my understanding of the updated rule I read I was very disappointed to see the rules for coordination of care with other health care providers, the sharing information in provision of integrated care and sharing information with health information exchanges was not streamlined - the regulations not reduced or changed for ease in these areas.  We continue to need specific permission from the patient to share this very critical medical information.  Withholding the information from coordination, from health information exchanges, and from the integrated care model causes care for the individual to be compromised.  The rules, from my perspective (someone who has worked with organizations servicing patients for over 30 years) continues to stigmatize the illness of addiction and continues to stigmatize addiction treatment.  Please consider eliminating the rules that require  authorization form the patient to share their treatment information with the providers who are providing treatment and care for the individual - we are providing treatment for the whole individual, not the individual minus the addiction.  This sort of restriction of information sometimes puts the patient at risk, they (the patient) choose not to share their addiction information so their providers or other aspects of their care are not aware of the treatment for addiction or their addiction and are then unable to include that variable in the treatment plan, sometime resulting in contra indicated treatments for the patient.

When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text: I concur with the proposed definition of dietary fiber and having it be labeled as fiber intact, isolated, and having beneficial health outcomes with them. I believe this will draw consumers to intake more dietary fiber, which is needed because the general population only intakes about half of the recommended amount of dietary fiber. Furthermore, I concur with mandating added sugars on the label. This is also important for the general population to see how many added sugars they intake. The general population intakes more than the recommended 10% of daily calories for sugars. Having added sugar on the label may also suggest to consumers that sugar naturally in the food is better than having added sugars. In this way, I think the general population may see how processed foods have a lot of added sugars like table sugar (by seeing how many grams)and intake less added sugars. However, I think there should be a percent of DRV implemented into the nutrition panel since the FDA recommends no more than 10% of daily calories from sugar. This would be a benefit to the general population for health. Lastly, the added sugar should only be zero if there is less than 0.5 gram of added sugars instead of only less than one gram.

Regarding DOT-OST-2014-0002, please prohibit airlines from allowing voice calls via passenger mobile wireless devices on domestic and/or international flights. An airplane is a publicly shared space. People already have a difficult time behaving civilly. Add the struggle to shout louder than the person in the adjacent seat and we have an instant conflict. Please do not allow cell phone conversations in flight.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: Please do NOT allow voice calls on Comercial airlines.  Besides being a safety issue, which should be obvious,  the repercussions of every passengers comfort and privacy would be compromised.  Imagine the noise? You'd have that business man conducting a meeting for HOURS, that other couple having phone sex, the people having a viscous heated argument - all of this going on in 6 different languages simultaneously. No thank you.j
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: Requiring airlines to announce to passengers ahead of time that their peace and quiet will be violated by cacophonous phone calls is like requiring criminals to tell victims ahead of time that they are about to be assaulted.  Doesn't do a lot of good.
