text:
DOT-OST-2014-0002
I am quoting verbatim as this person said it better than I could:
I would like to oppose the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft when the aircraft is in flight. The reason is one often does not know the person who is sitting next to them and so 1) confidential information could be released by the person on the phone subjecting them to identify theft or blackmail and 2) the party not on the phone has no where to escape and thus the personal space is being violated. The sanctity of the small aircraft space should be upheld. When the plane is on the ground that is fine for using the phones. Passengers who want to rest, read, relax will be held hostage to those who want to talk, possibly not even realizing if their voice is loud. This can cause uncivil interactions with other patrons and put undue stress upon the flight crew as well. Just as smoking was once allowed and is now banned, using mobile wireless devices should continue in the same vein for the health and well-being of all people aboard the plane. Thank you.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: This is a bad idea.  We have to listen to people on these phones while shopping, dining etc.  It is extremely annoying and would be exceptionally bad if trapped on an airplane listening to everyone jabbering on these phones.   Likewise i think it would be dangerous as someone with bad intentions could keep in contact with others who could do harm to all the passengers.  Please do not allow this.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
Please, do not allow inflight cell phone usage. Planes are already terribly confined, and if the person sharing my tight space were to be blathering on at the high volume required to be heard on a plane, it would be horribly offensive. Libraries remain quiet spaces, and planes should too.

All I ask is that you, as person, whomever is reading this, to imagine an international, coach seat, flight, middle seat, next to someone who is on their phone, and ask yourself if that is a good idea.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: I strongly support the EPA and the implementation of their proposed rule.

I strongly object to the use of wireless devices for voice calls on airlines. I believe that it will be subject to abuse, and I will refuse to fly with any airline that permits the person seated beside me to force me to listen to a one-way conversation.

In addition, airline travel is already stressful enough with the ever decreasing leg room, inconsiderate passengers who carry on more than the "allowed", long security lines  and fees for everything.  Travelers nowadays take an every man for himself mentality. Do we really want to give them one more way to be inconsiderate of others?

text: Please ban the use of cellular phones on domestic flights and international flights originating or terminating in the USA.  Control in the cabin is vital to airline and passenger safety.   To allow people to talk on the phone is a set-up for people to disregard the airline stewards in charge and to potentially have a volatile situation between passengers.  Thank you.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: I want to register my disapproval of the use of telephones to make calls during flight. The noise produced by any number of people speaking on their cell phones will be irritating and disruptive. Travel is stressful enough as it is without adding this additional aggravation.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
I do not mind a normal conversation between passengers on a flight, but I've never heard a "normal conversation" on a cell phone, even my own. For whatever reason, the callers elevate the volume of their conversation loud enough to be heard three or four (or more) tables away in a restaurant or a dozen seats away in a waiting area. Don't believe me? Go to the waiting area in any airport and there will be at least a dozen over-volume cellular telephone calls going at once. I can't imagine what it would be like to be on a cross country flight with cell calls going next to me, in front of me and behind me at the same time. And it will happen if passengers are allowed access to voice calls on a plane.

What about a little common courtesy and privacy in the back of the bus?
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
My idea of Hell is being trapped next to - or within earshot of - someone endlessly talking on a phone (or using anything that emits sound I can hear when I don't want to).

People survived millenia without being able to reach out and yack at someone 24/7. Staying off the phone while traveling in a closed container that no one can leave to avoid hearing their conversation is minimum civility, not a hardship.

Unfortunately, basic civility seems to be quite lacking in too many instances, so please keep the rule banning cell phone usage on flights! Travel is frustrating eno0ugh as it is. Banning phones means flights will be quieter, and as a side-effect, there will be less incentive to flight rage precipitated by loud, discourteous phone talkers.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
February 1, 2017

Stephen Ostroff, M.D.
Acting Commissioner
Division of Dockets Management (HFA-305)
Food and Drug Administration
5630 Fishers Lane, Room 1061
Rockville, MD 20852

Re: Docket No. FDA-2016-N-2527Tobacco Product Standard for N-Nitrosonornicotine (NNN) Level in Finished Smokeless Tobacco Products, 82 Fed. Reg. 8,004 (Jan. 23, 2017)

Reducing cancer-producing NNN is the easiest thing I have ever done; Ive done it thousands of times.Paraphrasing Mark Twain

We already have the prolonged federally unauthorized experimental paradigm and exegesis of light cigarettes, which clearly and convincingly testify to the fact that less nicotine in cigarettes translates into a higher risk for developing nicotine dependence and cancer. Light cigarettes are more zealously drawn upon, more deeply inhaled, retained in the lungs longer, and more often smoked down to the filter; in addition, more light cigarettes are smoked to achieve a comparable but temporary nicotine-induced focused, calm, and wellbeing cognitive result when compared to regular cigarettes, with the corresponding tobacco companies substantially increasing their revenue accordingly. It took a publication like The Clinical Management of Nicotine Dependence (1991) to serve as the legal substrate to the litany of lawsuits that followed.

Similarly, limiting NNN (N-nitrosonornicotine) in smokeless tobacco products is highly likely to further increase the incidence of nicotine dependence and cancer, while rallying the sales of light smokeless tobacco, thereby making smokeless tobacco product manufactures an even greater fortune.

It is just a matter of time before some addiction or healthy lifestyle guru publishes a comprehensive textbook on the clinical management of smokeless tobacco products (or the equivalent), and the smokeless tobacco product companies will not have the very deep pockets and the compellingly vast international following that helped tobacco companies survive and prosper.

The FDA might consider scrapping this NNN Docket to sculpt a newer one to include but not be limited to: 1) warning labels on all smokeless tobacco products; 2) new quit smokeless tobacco public service announcements and ads, channeled into the already existing quit smoking infrastructure; 3) mandatory health insurance, life insurance, Social Security, and disability urine NNN screens, with corresponding premium hikes or benefit depletions based on positive NNN results; 4) 30% food stamp (SNAP) allocations toward fresh fruit and 30% toward fresh vegetables to help prevent cancer born of systemic oxidative stress caused by NNN; and 5) suggestions to smokeless tobacco product manufacturers that they tool up for an alternative product production, such as beginning to annex themselves with pharmaceutical companies to help develop new inhaler delivery systems for certain established pharmaceutical products.

The money state and federal governments might lose from taxes of smokeless tobacco products and industries may be gained from pertinently stepping up insurance premiums, stepping down benefits, shortening hospital and long-term care stays, and prolonging productivity and spending.

This Docket should be scrapped in its entirety and resubmitted in a form that benefits all sides of the trade.

If you require additional information or have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me by email.

Respectfully submitted,
James A. Cocores, M.D.
Editor, The Clinical Management of Nicotine Dependence, Springer International
Consultant, Royal Life Centers
Founder, Psychephysics Research Institute

Edited by SERVICESCAPE XpertEditor

PLEASE do not allow cell phone calls on planes!  Seats have gotten so small that we no longer have personal space.  Being forced to listen to someone talk loudly about personal matters will only increase air rage.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: NO- Please do NOT allow cell phones to be used on planes. Space it too confined; people are TOO rude and inconsiderate! PLEASE PLEASE do NOT make air travel any more unpleasant than it already is. Almost ALL phone conversations can wait until the plane lands. Thank you.
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: I know that I will go bonkers if forced to listen to calls made by fellow-passengers!   Flying is becoming more and more unpleasant and those calls will send me right over the edge.  It  can only lead to ugliness from sane people.  When I fly I love the silence and solitude allowing me to read in peace.  Who ever came up with this loony idea?   Please, please, no, no, no!
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
